name: Cardiac Pacing
contents:
Cardiac Pacing

Surgeons put in Epicardium (ie, outside of heart - because they need to take off). 

Indications :

  1. Weaning off of CPB (because during CPB cardioplegic , ie asystolic) 
    • can take time to get back heart rhythm
    • RV pacing wires - to take off bypass - temporary indication
  2. AV nodal dysfunction 
    1. normally valve or open heart 
    2. AV (local to valves) fibrous skeleton - surrounding valves - aortic valve surgery in particular --> PPM (2%) 
      1. Direct physical damage 
      2. Oedema of AV node (may occur up to 72hrs after surgery) 
        1. Epicardial pacing is a bridge to recovery
  3. Prevention or treatment of secondary bradycardias in high risk patients 
    1. pre-existent AVN disease 
    2. surgeries with increased risk of bleeding/ischemia/surgical
    3. patients with complex co-morbities 
    4. -> Ventricular pacing system is required. 
  4. Optimisation of post-operative cardiac output 
    1. this requires use of an atrial pacing system (unless pt. has persistent AF) **arguably most important. 

Ventricular pacing can be acutely life-saving  -however if you have integretity of AV nodal conduction - then the patient can become hypotensive. 

1st Letter: Pacing, 2nd letter: Sensing, 3rd Letter: Effect (from sensed)

4 Outcomes of DDD Mode 

  1. Both leads inhibited/sensing only 'back up' normal sinus - no pacing spikes
  2. Pacing atria/sensing ventricles = rhythm is 'atrially paced' same as AAI
  3. Sensing atria/pacing ventricles = 'tracking the atrial rate' treating heart block ; same as VDD 
  4. Pacing both atria and ventricles 'AV sequential pacing' 2 pacing spikes

Pacing settings

  • Pacing capture - how much voltage required to pace
    • capture threshold - at what point does the pacing not produce a QRS -> then programme unit to x2-3 threshold 
    • Normal impedence (200-1500 ohms) - so I = V/R(impedence) so increasing voltage can overcome higher impedence caused by poor wires/system
    • Low capture <3V = good 
  • Sensing - sensing threshold is the amplitude of R wave 
    • so set VSense to be 1/3 of that so that it captures every R wave and therefore every asystole, but is higher than interference/artefact 
    • High R wave is better (stronger) eg 6mV giving Vsense of 2mV 
    • Having to set it lower would pick up interference.

name: Glyceryl trinitrate
contents:
CUP A DORSET DAME


Chemical: Glyceryl trinitrate (GTN) is an organic nitrate

Uses:

Presentation : prepared in the following formulations: an aerosol spray delivering 400 micrograms per metered dose and tablets containing 300-600 micrograms, both used sublingually.

name: Optics
question1: 1. PULSE OXIMETRY: HOW DOES IT WORK? IS IT FAST OR SLOW AS A MONITOR OF OXYGEN SATURATION? WHAT PROBLEMS ARE ASSOCIATED WITH IT?
contents:
A probe is placed on the finger, toe, ear lobe or nose. 


  • Two light-emitting diodes produce beams at red and infrared frequencies (660 nm and 940 nm, respectively). 
  • There is a photo detector on the other side. 
  • The diodes flash at approximately 30 times per second. 
  • The diodes are switched on in sequence, with a pause with both diodes off. (This allows compensation for ambient light.)
  • The microprocessor analyses the changes in light absorption during the arterial pulsatile flow (AC) and ignores the non-pulsatile component of the signal (which results from the tissues and venous blood).
  • Pulsatile flow - The photo detector generates a voltage proportional to the transmitted light. 

The oxygen saturation is estimated by measuring the transmission of light through the pulsatile tissue bed.

This is based on the Beer-Lambert law:

Beer-Lambert law : This is a combination of two laws describing absorption of monochromatic light by a transparent substance through which it passes:

Beer's law: The Intensity of light received decreases exponentially as the concentration of the substance through which it travels increases.

A=ln(Io/I) (Io = Intensity of original light)

Lambert’s law: the intensity of transmitted light decreases exponentially as the distance travelled through the substance increases. 

The microprocessor analyses both the DC (non-pulsatile) and AC (pulsatile) components at 660 nm and 940 nm. The absorption of oxyhaemoglobin and deoxyhaemoglobin at these two wavelengths is very different. Hence, these two wavelengths provide good sensitivity.

A = ε x l x C (where A is the Absorbance of the solution) epsilon is the molar absorption coefficient. it compensates for variance in concentration and the path-length to allow comparison between solutions.


Problems associated:

Poor perfusion, Movement artefact, electrical interference from diathermy, highly calloused skin, nail varnish, severe anaemia, cardiac arrhythmia, methaemoglobinaemia increased venous pulsation eg severe tricuspid regurg. IV admin of methylene blue dye.

The following can cause high readings : CO poisoning CO irreversibly binds to Hb. Cyanide poisoning = this is not inaccurate cyanide prevents O2 being utilised in respiration and so its extraction for the blood falls meaning saturations are high.
question2: Lasers : Acronym for:, Describe basic principles, fundamental components, different types, classification, hazards, precautions.
contents2:
Light amplification by the stimulated emission of radiation.


Principle :

  • Spontaneous emission : (electrons) spontaneous decay results in the emission of a photon with the same energy as the difference between the excited state and the ground state. (wavelength is inversely proportional to the energy difference between the two states).
  • Stimulated emission : (in this scenario electrons are already in their excited state) other photons in the vicinity of the atom can effect the atoms state. Specifically the atom will oscillate slightly as the photon passes, because the electrons are electrically charged and therefore respond to the photon, essentially an oscillating electric field. The oscillation encourages electrons to decay to the lower energy state - when an incident photon causes a decay the emitted photon is emitted at exactly the same time as the passing photon, the the photons are said to be in phase, and they travel away in the same direction --> ultimately (by the use of a partially reflective mirror on one side) causing a beam of monochromatic, collimated (a fine beam), coherent. :

Components:

  1. External energy source
  2. Laser medium
  3. Chamber containing laser medium
  4. System of mirrors - allowing amplification + partially reflective mirror to allow collimated beam to exit the system.
  5. Windows at each end of the deice are inclined to Brewster's angle (this is the angle of incidence at which light is perfectly transmitted with no reflection, thereby ensuring that 100% of the light is transmitted through the windows)
  6. Fibre-optic cable (to direct the laser beam)
